info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship final game 2.
From Yale University.
Game data retrieved from an alternate archive.

(1, 1).clue: Statues of this religious figure feature a knot of hair covering a second brain that contains his enlightenment

(2, 1).clue: The nonfiction "Fallout" is about Leo Szilard, J. Robert Oppenheimer & the "political science" of this weapon

(3, 1).clue: Proverbially, "it takes two" to perform this dance

(4, 1).clue: Founded in 1995, this auction site calls itself "the world's online marketplace"

(6, 1).clue: It means to read messages in an online chat forum without contributing yourself

(1, 2).clue: The Ramayana is an epic story in this religion that tells the tale of Prince Rama & his attempts to rescue Sita

(2, 2).clue: Eric Shanower's "A Thousand Ships", a graphic novel about this war, opens with the story of Paris kidnapping Helen

(3, 2).clue: Serpentine name for a dice roll of a one & a one

(4, 2).clue: The icon seen here  represents this company

(6, 2).clue: The inclusion of this trademark toxin should raise a few eyebrows, or rather, freeze them in place

(1, 3).clue: Every Muslim must fast during this month, the month the first verses of the Koran were revealed to Muhammad

(2, 3).clue: "From Hell" recounts this notorious figure's crimes in Victorian England

(3, 3).clue: The condition of holding full legal status in 2 different countries

(4, 3).clue: Western musician Wylie Gustafson yodels the name of this company at the end of its commercials

(6, 3).clue: Not a female lawyer, it's someone who serves coffee, especially at Starbucks

(1, 4).clue: The Great Purification Ceremony is one of the most important rituals in this, Japan's oldest religion

(2, 4).clue: This graphic novel about 1930s gangsters by Collins & Rayner became a Tom Hanks film

(3, 4).clue: Its "second law" states that heat always flows from a hotter object to a colder object

(4, 4).clue: This saint presides over the internal search engine at americancatholic.org

(6, 4).clue: You can name this surgical operation that reshapes the cornea to correct myopia in 5 letters

(1, 5).clue: In Avesta, this Iranian religion's sacred book, only the sacrificial prayers are attributed to its founder

(2, 5).clue: This graphic novel made it to the big screen in 2003 with Sean Connery as Allan Quatermain

(3, 5).clue: From the Latin for "two-headed", it's the arm muscle that bends the elbow

(4, 5).clue: This butler seen here does the searching for you at ask.com

(6, 5).clue: A brief & insignificant rise in a stock price after a steep decline is a "dead" this "bounce"

(1, 1).clue: Like his brother Peyton of the Colts, Eli Manning has made a name for himself playing this position

(2, 1).clue: These insects make up the animal kingdom's largest order; over 600 species may be found in 1 rainforest tree

(3, 1).clue: In 1994 Meryl provided the voice of Bart's naughty little girlfriend Jessica Lovejoy on this series

(4, 1).clue: He was the Englishman whose blood was smelled by a fe-fi-fo-fummer

(5, 1).clue: Yale's chaplain William Sloane Coffin was convicted of helping young men avoid this

(6, 1).clue: What a social climber! His name precedes "symbol" to mean something that represents high position

(1, 2).clue: This pharmaceutical company introduced Prozac to a grateful world in the 1980s

(2, 2).clue: Divers seek the butterfly fish and other colorful creatures in this type of habitat, like Australia's "Great" one

(4, 2).clue: In 1995 he played "The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain"

(5, 2).clue: FSM, formed by Berkeley protesters in 1964, stood for this "movement"

(6, 2).clue: His hand turned red when he touched orange juice, blue when he touched seawater

(2, 3).clue: You'd find the marsh hen & the swamp lily in these, a general term for areas like marshes & swamps

(4, 3).clue: In this peripatetic book, Jules Verne wrote, "An Englishman does not joke about such an important matter as a bet"
(4, 3).correct response: Around the World in Eighty Days

(5, 3).clue: Wisconsin kids protested campus recruitment by this chemical company, maker of Napalm

(6, 3).clue: In Rome his name meant simply "good"; to us it implies that he gave a little something extra

(2, 4).clue: This U.S. national park is the only place where alligators & crocodiles exist side by side

(5, 4).clue: In 1968 at this NYC university, students took over President Kirk's office & even drank his sherry

(6, 4).clue: His name came from the Latin for "dispute" & he would drag you into court any chance he got
